text.#text:
In reviewing rules and small entity
				compliance guides under paragraph (1), the agency shall determine
			 whether the
				rules and guides should—

be amended or rescinded, consistent
				with the stated objectives of applicable statutes, to minimize any
			 significant
				adverse economic impacts on a substantial number of small entities
			 (including
				an estimate of any adverse impacts on job creation and employment
			 by small
				entities); or

continue in effect without
				change.

Each agency shall publish the plan
				established under paragraph (1) in the Federal Register and on the
			 Web site of
				the agency.

An agency may amend the plan
				established under paragraph (1) at any time by publishing the
			 amendment in the
				Federal Register and on the Web site of the agency.

Each plan
				established under subsection (a) shall provide for—

the review of
				each rule and small entity compliance guide described in subsection
			 (a)(1) in
				effect on the date of enactment of the

not later than 9
				years after the date of publication of the plan in the Federal
			 Register;
				and

every 9 years
				thereafter; and

				(a)(1) that is published after the date of enactment of the

not later than 9

In reviewing
				rules under the plan required under subsection (a), the agency
			 shall
				consider—

the continued
				need for the rule;

the nature of
				complaints received by the agency from small entities concerning
			 the
				rule;

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Chief Counsel for Advocacy
			 of the
				Small Business Administration

text.#text: comments by the

the complexity of
				the rule;

the extent to
				which the rule overlaps, duplicates, or conflicts with other
			 Federal rules and,
				unless the head of the agency determines it to be infeasible, State
			 and local
				rules;

the contribution
				of the rule to the cumulative economic impact of all Federal rules
			 on the class
				of small entities affected by the rule, unless the head of the
			 agency
				determines that such a calculation cannot be made;

the length of
				time since the rule has been evaluated, or the degree to which
			 technology,
				economic conditions, or other factors have changed in the area
			 affected by the
				rule; and

the economic
				impact of the rule, including—

the estimated
				number of small entities to which the rule will apply;

the estimated
				number of small entity jobs that will be lost or created due to the
			 rule;
				and

the projected
				reporting, recordkeeping, and other compliance requirements of the
			 proposed
				rule, including—

an estimate of
				the classes of small entities that will be subject to the
			 requirement;
				and

the type of
				professional skills necessary for preparation of the report or
			 record.

Each agency shall
				submit an annual report regarding the results of the review
			 required under
				subsection (a) to—
Congress; and

Administrator of the Office of Information and Regulatory

				Office of Management and Budget

a brief

notify the head of the agency

Nothing in this paragraph may be

header.#text: Sunset of new small business regulations

text.#text:
Except as provided in subsection (b) and beginning on the date of enactment of this Act, each
			 covered rule promulgated by an agency shall cease to have effect on the
			 date that is 7 years after the
			 date on which the final version of the covered rule is published.

Before the end of the 7-year period described in subsection (a), an agency may take action to renew
			 a covered rule in accordance with the process described in paragraph (2)
			 and if such action is taken, the covered rule shall remain in effect until
			 modified
			 or repealed by the agency action or statute.
An agency may renew a covered rule by using the notice and comment rulemaking process.
solicit and respond to public comment from entities affected by the covered rule;

consider whether any regulatory alternatives exist that would accomplish the same regulatory
			 objective as the covered rule with less of an impact on affected small
			 entities; and
make modifications to the covered rule, if necessary, to reflect—

comments solicited under
			 clause (i);
modifications described in clause (ii); and
any regulatory alternatives described in clause (iii).
In conducting a rulemaking to renew a covered rule under subparagraph (A), an agency shall—
